user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarDelete_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarDelete_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32                              final_status;
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    final_status = OS_SUCCESS;
    impl         = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    status = pthread_cond_destroy(&impl->cv);
    if (status != 0)
    {
        final_status = OS_ERROR;
    }

    status = pthread_mutex_destroy(&impl->mut);
    if (status != 0)
    {
        final_status = OS_ERROR;
    }

    return final_status;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CondVarDelete_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t OS_impl_condvar_table[OS_MAX_CONDVARS]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t mut;
    pthread_cond_t  cv;
} OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no uses of any string handling functions from <string.h> (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) in the provided function OS_CondVarDelete_Impl or in the related definitions. The code only calls pthread_cond_destroy and pthread_mutex_destroy and uses the OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro to index an array of OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t, which contains pthread_mutex_t and pthread_cond_t members (no character buffers or string operations). The OS_ObjectIndexFromToken inline simply returns token->obj_idx and does not perform any string handling. Therefore there are no code fragments here that could violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17; no string.h function calls or string-pointer-based accesses exist in the supplied code. (Note: general bounds checking of the array index is a separate concern but is not related to Rule 21.17, which specifically targets string.h functions.)
